subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Interfaith Dialogue: Can Religions Get Along?
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Interfaith Dialogue: Can Religions Get Along?.

hook.text: In 1893, a Hindu monk spoke at the Parliament of Religions in Chicago. He opened with 'brothers and sisters of America.'

buildup.text: Swami Vivekananda's speech launched the interfaith movement. For the first time, religions met as equals, not rivals.

discovery.text: Modern interfaith work focuses on shared values: compassion, justice, and service. Theology divides; ethics can unite.

twist.text: Critics say interfaith dialogue waters down all faiths. If every path leads to God, why commit to any one of them?

climax.text: Interfaith work doesn't ask religions to agree. It asks them to cooperate. Action matters more than belief.

punchline.text: Religions don't need to agree. They need to cooperate. Action beats theology.

quiz.question: What is the goal of interfaith dialogue?
options: To find shared values and cooperate on common goals despite theological differences
